sites.title: Unforgettable Adventures Qaphael
sites.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Ut sequi, rem magnam nesciunt minima placeat.

overview.text: Qaphael Uganda, often referred to as the 'Pearl of Africa,' boasts diverse landscapes, abundant wildlife, and rich cultural heritage. From the misty mountains of Bwindi to the expansive savannas of Queen Elizabeth National Park, Uganda offers a unique safari experience.

keyInfo.highSeason: June to September (Popular parks may be crowded)

pros: Scenic landscapes including mountains and lakes
cons: Malaria is prevalent; precautions are necessary qaph

list.name: James Wilson
list.text: Exceptional quality and outstanding customer service. The attention to detail is remarkable.

list.name: Sarah Thompson
list.text: Great value for money. The product exceeded my expectations in terms of functionality.

list.name: Michael Brown
list.text: The adventure activities were the highlight of our trip! The guides were knowledgeable and made everything so much fun.

list.name: Emily Davis
list.text: The travel insurance gave us peace of mind during our trip. Thankfully, we didn’t need it, but it was great to know we were covered.

wildlife.text: Uganda is home to a variety of wildlife, including the Big Five. The country is particularly renowned for its primate population, especially the endangered mountain gorillas and chimpanzees.
wildlife.activities: Popular activities include gorilla and chimpanzee trekking, game drives, bird watching, boat safaris, and cultural tours.

bestTime.text: The dry seasons from June to August and December to February are ideal for wildlife viewing and trekking activities.
bestTime.weather: Uganda enjoys a tropical climate with two dry seasons (December to February, June to August) and two wet seasons (March to May, September to November). Temperatures are generally pleasant, ranging from 21°C to 25°C (70°F to 77°F).

premierParks.name: QaphaelEtosha National Park
premierParks.description: Classic safaris with abundant wildlife during the Dry season.

premierParks.name: Namib-Naukluft National Park
premierParks.description: Stunning desert scenery with iconic sand dunes like Sossusvlei.

allParks.name: Etosha National Park
allParks.description: Classic safaris with abundant wildlife during the Dry season.

allParks.name: Namib-Naukluft National Park
allParks.description: Stunning desert scenery with iconic sand dunes like Sossusvlei.

allParks.name: Skeleton Coast National Park
allParks.description: Beautiful desert coastline with wildlife, though scarce.

allParks.name: Bwabwata National Park
allParks.description: Classic safaris featuring giraffe and four of the Big Five (no rhino).

allParks.name: |Ai-|Ais/Richtersveld Transfrontier Park
allParks.description: Hiking paradise with stunning desert scenery and scarce wildlife.

allParks.name: Damaraland
allParks.description: Home to desert-adapted elephants, lions, and rare rhinos.

wildlife.text: Uganda is home to a variety of wildlife, including the Big Five. The country is particularly renowned for its primate population, especially the endangered mountain gorillas and chimpanzees.
wildlife.activities: Popular activities include gorilla and chimpanzee trekking, game drives, bird watching, boat safaris, and cultural tours.

bestTime.text: The dry seasons from June to August and December to February are ideal for wildlife viewing and trekking activities.
bestTime.weather: Uganda enjoys a tropical climate with two dry seasons (December to February, June to August) and two wet seasons (March to May, September to November). Temperatures are generally pleasant, ranging from 21°C to 25°C (70°F to 77°F).

gettingThere.text: Uganda is accessible by air, with Entebbe International Airport being the main gateway. Several airlines offer direct flights from major cities worldwide.
gettingThere.passport: A passport is required for all foreign visitors and must be valid for at least six months.
gettingThere.visa: Citizens from most countries do not require a visa and will receive a 30-day entry permit on arrival.
gettingThere.children: Children under 18 must have a certified copy of their full, unabridged birth certificate and a valid passport. If traveling with only one parent or no parents, an affidavit from the missing parent(s) is required.

safety.text: Uganda is a relatively safe country for tourists. However, it's important to take precautions against petty theft and scams, especially in urban areas. It's also advisable to consult your doctor about necessary vaccinations and malaria prevention.
safety.wildlife: Your safari guide will prioritize your safety at all times. Listen carefully to their instructions and always follow the park rules. When on a self-drive safari, don’t drive too close to wildlife and only leave your car in designated areas where it is safe to do so.
safety.cities: Namibian cities are relatively safe. Most crime issues are minor, such as petty theft and pickpocketing. On an organized tour, you will mostly be sheltered from these risks by your guide. When venturing out in cities unguided, you can reduce being at risk by following a few simple precautions:
citiesList: Get advice at your hotel before taking a walk in the city.
Don’t carry any valuables and only take limited money with you.
Don’t walk after dark; rather take a taxi.
Never leave valuables visible in your car.
